moving requirement to python3-ready ambition fork of django-uuidfield
moving requirement to python3-ready ambition fork of django-uuidfield

issue_comments.body: @jaredlewis I decided to go with a public ambition fork instead of using Django's native `UUIDField`, since there isn't any support for uuid's without hyphens in the native field, and we're using hyphen-free uuid's. We could do migrations to move all uuid fields to other names and make properties that remove hyphens, but I figured this is simpler.
LGTM

issue_comments.body: @Wilduck had one comment about a query you were doing
@Wilduck you may want to use ENTITY_EMAILER_DEFAULT_FROM as the setting variable instead. I bet many people use a DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL variable for other things
@Wilduck you left a print statement in there. ready to merge when its gone
@Wilduck im good to merge when jeff's comments are addressed

@Wilduck this upgrades entity emailer to use entity event. It provides all of the migrations necessary to convert the emails to use new sources. This PR also includes functions and tasks to convert events into emails, making entity emailer more tightly integrated with events.
FYI @micahhausler

review_comments.body: unique=True
subentity_type = foreignkey (ContentType, null=True)

The naming convention erik uses is if he is testing a single function of a class, it uses Test with the function name. Ive seen this used in a couple other places and have seen other python style guides that say this is the only acceptable time to use non-camel case class names.
@Wilduck are there style guides that promote this convention? Ive been meaning to copy the google style guide in, but I dont think the google style guide talks about this convention
handle_email_save(sender, instance, **kwargs):
dont_send_to = Unsubscribed.objects.filter(unsubscribed_from=email.email_type).values_list('user', flat=True)
set(entity.id for entity in all_entities)
.iterator()

from django.template.loader import render_to_string

message_text = render_to_string(email_text_template, email_text_context)
message_html = render_to_string(email_html_template, email_html_context)

When you do this, underneath the hood Django is reading in all of those entity fields, parsing all of the json of the entity meta, and doing a bunch of unneeded work everytime an email is sent. Doing this should be equivalent and much more efficient:

``` python
dont_sent_to = frozenset(Unsubscribed.objects.filter(unsubscribed_from=email.email_type).values_list('entity', flat=True))

send_to = (entity for entity in all_entities if entity.id not in dont_sent_to)  # or use ifilter instead
```

You could also try to structure it all as a set operation, but you will also have to built a map of entity ids to entities and then access that map O(n) times as well
you left the print in
FYI Django 1.7 is changing this chaos and send_mail will take an html_message argument https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/email/#send-mail
return getattr(settings, 'ENTITY_EMAILER_FROM_EMAIL', settings.DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL)

``` python
from django.test.util import override_settings

@override_settings(ENTITY_EMAILER_FROM_EMAIL='test_entity@example.com')
def test_entity...
```

issue_comments.body: Comments addressed.

@wesleykendall This build is failing, and it looks like it's because of something in django-entity. It runs fine locally, but when [run on travis](https://travis-ci.org/Wilduck/django-entity-emailer/builds/25700620) it spits out this error:

```
error: /home/travis/build/Wilduck/django-entity-emailer/django_entity-0.3.5-py2.7.egg/entity/migrations: Not a directory
```

It seems that django-entity is missing a "migrations" directory? Any thoughts?
@wesleykendall @jmcriffey Comments addressed. Thanks for looking over this.

@wesleykendall I implemented your performance optimization, and also created the option for a user to set `settings.ENTITY_EMAILER_FROM_EMAIL`. If that value is set, it will be sent in the from field, otherwise the `DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL` will be used.
@jmcriffey @wesleykendall Comments addressed.
@wesleykendall @jmcriffey I've addressed the stylistic issues here. I'm going to merge this and start a new branch to take care of concurrency issues.
This looks good to me @wesleykendall. Merging.

review_comments.body:
Specifically the naming convention is `Test_MyClassName_some_method_name(TestCase)` for methods and `Test_my_function_name(TestCase)` for functions.

I think this makes at least some sense in the context of tests, since our test-loader is doing introspection on the class names to find tests, and serves as a clear demarcation of the code under test.

I'm trying to find where I found this originally and coming up short. I saw it around the time I was first learning to test python a few years ago. It made sense at the time and kind of stuck with me.

I think all camel-case names are more common, and while I find it harder to tell at a glance what is being tested I could live with that convention.

Not to muddle the issue further, but I'm curious how you feel on the issue of `class TestMyClass(TestCase)` vs `class MyClassTest(TestCase)` and `def test_some_property(self)` vs `some_property_test(self)`. I've always preferred the former, but I think I see the later about equally often.

I'll see if I can't find a reference for the naming convention I'm used to using.
Done, just in a slightly different spot.
Makes sense to me.
This should now be addressed. Except for the case of a bulk create, `ValidationError` will be raised for any `EmailTemplate` that could lead to this statement being false.
You definitely can. Buy why would you when `C-c C-c n` automatically re-numbers any out of order numeric lists in your current buffer?
Oh, I see why. Because I had them miss-numbered. I guess that's what I get for being a smart aleck.
:thumbsup:
I think this is a bit too big for me to be comfortable with a list comprehension.

issue_comments.body: Looks good to me. :guitar:
Looking good @Wilduck. I would like to see some logic and tests for enforcing the rules that you describe for email templates.
@Wilduck Looks good. Just had a couple of minor comments.

review_comments.body: Maybe show a test model here with an appropriate entity_meta.
NewletterSubscribers -> NewsletterSubscribers
NewletterSubscribers - > NewsletterSubscribers
Remove extra newline for consistency.
Could you call this HandleEmailSaveTests? I believe that is what it would be called in our Ambition repo.
Same comment here as above: GetEmailAddressesTests

This style bugs me for some reason. I think deviates from our normal naming schema too much. 
I could see `handle_email_save_test` being a good alternative. I think the mixing of camel and snake is throwing me off.

Where have we seen the Test_method_name used style before?

It would be nice to handle this case specifically and unify our naming conventions. If we are going to stick with `Test_my_function_name`, then maybe the rest of our code could should follow that pattern. That is, using `Test_MyClassName` and `Test_MyClassName_my_method` instead of `MyClassNameTest`.
What happens if you set `template_text`, `template_html`, `text_template_path`, and `html_template_path`? What order do these fields take precedence?
What happens if they are? Is there saving error?
I don't see any logic that enforces this statement. You might want to override the save method in your EmailTemplate model or `assert rendered_text or rendered_html` to ensure this state.
Just for future reference, you can do `1.` for all list items and it will auto number them.
You might be able to do a list comprehension here.
